Covariance Bell Inequalities

Victor Pozsgay Département de Physique Appliquée, Université de Genève, 1211 Genève, Switzerland    Flavien Hirsch Département de Physique Appliquée, Université de Genève, 1211 Genève, Switzerland    Cyril Branciard Univ. Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, Grenoble INP111Institute of Engineering Univ. Grenoble Alpes, Institut Néel, 38000 Grenoble, France    Nicolas Brunner Département de Physique Appliquée, Université de Genève, 1211 Genève, Switzerland
(3rd March 2024)
Abstract

We introduce Bell inequalities based on covariance, one of the most common measures of correlation. Explicit examples are discussed, and violations in quantum theory are demonstrated. A crucial feature of these covariance Bell inequalities is their nonlinearity; this has nontrivial consequences for the derivation of their local bound, which is not reached by deterministic local correlations. For our simplest inequality, we derive analytically tight bounds for both local and quantum correlations. An interesting application of covariance Bell inequalities is that they can act as “shared randomness witnesses”: specifically, the value of the Bell expression gives device-independent lower bounds on both the dimension and the entropy of the shared random variable in a local model.

Bell inequalities limit the strength of possible correlations for any model satisfying a natural definition of locality formulated by Bell bell64 . Thus, the violation of a Bell inequality indicates that no local model (in the sense of Bell) can reproduce the observed data, which is therefore said to be (Bell) nonlocal. This can be the case in quantum theory where, by performing well-chosen local measurements on an entangled quantum system, one may obtain nonlocal quantum correlations.

Beyond their fundamental interest, Bell inequalities are widely used tools, in particular in quantum information science review . Indeed, a Bell inequality violation represents a simple and strong test for certifying the presence of entanglement. Importantly this test is device-independent, in the sense that, assuming quantum theory, a Bell inequality violation implies the presence of entanglement without any assumption on the measuring devices, nor on the Hilbert space dimension. Moreover, the violation of a Bell inequality can also be used to certify the presence of genuine quantum randomness colbeck ; pironio , or the security of a cryptographic key acin .

Consider two separate observers, performing local measurement on a shared physical system. The experiment results in some data, namely the joint conditional probabilities of observing a pair of outputs (measurement results) given a pair of inputs (choice of measurement settings). As they capture the strength of correlations in the data, it is intuitive that Bell inequalities are constructed based on some measure of correlation. For instance, the simplest and most famous Bell inequality of Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt (CHSH) chsh is a linear combination of simple correlation functions (see below). As these correlation functions are themselves linear combinations of the joint conditional probabilities, the CHSH inequality is a so-called linear Bell inequality. More generally, it is known that the set of distributions that are Bell local can be fully characterized via linear Bell inequalities Pitowsky89 , and great efforts have been dedicated to find such inequalities, see e.g. Refs. pitowsky ; sliwa ; CG ; I4422 ; tamas ; rosset .

It is however natural to ask if other measures of correlations can be used for devising Bell inequalities. Beyond the purely conceptual interest, this could be relevant in a practical context in which the full data is not available, but only certain specific (not necessarily linear) functions of the joint probabilities are. Moreover, it would be interesting to devise new types of Bell inequalities for the case of continuous measurement outcomes, for which the standard approach for constructing linear inequalities does not work anymore.

Several works have explored these ideas. First, entropic Bell inequalities bc ; cerf ; chaves were obtained by considering the mutual information between the measurement outcomes. Later, inequalities based on higher moments of the distribution were also derived eric ; salles ; belzig ; bednorz . Finally, nonlinear Bell inequalities have been developed for discussing the generalization of Bell nonlocality to networks branciard ; biloc2 ; armin ; chaves16 ; rosset16 .

Here we introduce a novel class of nonlinear Bell inequalities based on the covariance of measurement results, a natural measure of correlations that is widely used in many different areas of science. We propose a general way to construct such Bell inequalities for covariances, and present, in the simplest case, a method for computing their local bound—a nontrivial problem due to the nonlinearity of the Bell expression. We show on a few explicit examples that our inequalities can detect quantum nonlocality. Moreover, we show that covariance Bell inequalities can be used to characterize shared randomness in a Bell test, providing device-independent lower bounds on the dimension and the entropy of the shared random variable in any local model.

Standard Bell inequalities.—

Consider an experiment in which two parties, Alice and Bob, can both locally test different properties of a shared physical system. Let us label by x𝑥x the measurement choice of Alice and y𝑦y that of Bob, with the corresponding outcomes defining the random variables Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} and Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y}, which take the values a𝑎a and b𝑏b, respectively. We will only consider non-signalling scenarios, in which the statistics of Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} do not depend on the choice of y𝑦y, and similarly the statistics of Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} do not depend on x𝑥x.

The statistics of the whole experiment, and thereby the correlations between Alice and Bob’s measurement outcomes, are characterized by the joint conditional probability distribution P​(a,b|x,y)=P​(Ax=a,By=b)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦𝑃formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝑥𝑎subscript𝐵𝑦𝑏P(a,b|x,y)=P(A_{x}=a,B_{y}=b). Such a distribution is called local (in the sense of Bell) if it admits a decomposition of the form

P​(a,b|x,y)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦\displaystyle P(a,b|x,y) =∫ρ​(λ)​PA​(a|x,λ)​PB​(b|y,λ)​𝑑λ,absent𝜌𝜆subscript𝑃𝐴conditional𝑎𝑥𝜆subscript𝑃𝐵conditional𝑏𝑦𝜆differential-d𝜆\displaystyle=\int\rho(\lambda)\;P_{A}(a|x,\lambda)\;P_{B}(b|y,\lambda)\;d\lambda, (1)

where λ𝜆\lambda represents the possible values a shared classical variable ΛΛ\Lambda (shared randomness), distributed with the density function ρ​(λ)𝜌𝜆\rho(\lambda). The local response functions, defined by the distributions PA​(a|x,λ)subscript𝑃𝐴conditional𝑎𝑥𝜆P_{A}(a|x,\lambda) and PB​(b|y,λ)subscript𝑃𝐵conditional𝑏𝑦𝜆P_{B}(b|y,\lambda) represent the local behavior of Alice and Bob’s subsystems.

The set of local distributions—the “local set”—is constrained by linear Bell inequalities of the form

B=∑x,y,a,bαa​b|x​y​P​(a,b|x,y)≤β,Bsubscript𝑥𝑦𝑎𝑏subscript𝛼conditional𝑎𝑏𝑥𝑦𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦𝛽\displaystyle\text{B}\,=\sum_{x,y,a,b}\alpha_{ab|xy}\ P(a,b|x,y)\,\leq\,\beta, (2)

with some real coefficients αa​b|x​ysubscript𝛼conditional𝑎𝑏𝑥𝑦\alpha_{ab|xy}, and where the “local bound” β𝛽\beta is the maximal value of the quantity B over all local distributions. For any given (finite) number of possible measurement settings and outcomes, the local set forms a polytope, and is thus fully characterized by a finite set of such linear Bell inequalities Pitowsky89 .

As a concrete example, consider the case of two measurements for each party, labelled by x,y∈{0,1}𝑥𝑦01x,y\in\{0,1\}, with binary outcomes a,b∈{+1,−1}𝑎𝑏11a,b\in\{+1,-1\}. Here we have the well-known CHSH inequality chsh

CHSH≡⟨A0​B0⟩+⟨A0​B1⟩+⟨A1​B0⟩−⟨A1​B1⟩≤2,CHSHdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵12\displaystyle\text{CHSH}\equiv\langle A_{0}B_{0}\rangle{+}\langle A_{0}B_{1}\rangle{+}\langle A_{1}B_{0}\rangle{-}\langle A_{1}B_{1}\rangle\leq 2,\quad\ (3)

where the correlation functions ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle are simply defined as the expectation values of the products of outcomes, ⟨Ax​By⟩=∑a,ba​b​P​(a,b|x,y)delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦subscript𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle=\sum_{a,b}a\,b\,P(a,b|x,y). Like many other linear Bell inequalities, the CHSH inequality can detect quantum nonlocal correlations, obtained by performing well chosen local measurements on a shared entangled state.

A Bell inequality for covariances.—

Instead of using the correlation functions ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, other quantities can also be considered to characterize local distributions; indeed, Bell inequalities were for instance constructed for entropic quantities bc ; cerf ; chaves . In this work we focus on another natural and widely used measure of correlation, namely the covariance. As mentioned previously, this may be of practical interest for situations where the full data is not available, and only covariances can be estimated. An advantage of using covariances is also that, like entropies, they are naturally defined for any number of possible measurement outcomes, and even for continuous outcomes. Unlike entropies however, they depend on the specific values given to the measurement outcomes; this allows one, in particular, to distinguish correlations versus anti-correlations.

The covariance of the two output variables Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} and Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} is defined as

cov​(Ax,By)=⟨Ax​By⟩−⟨Ax⟩​⟨By⟩,covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\displaystyle\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})=\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle-\langle A_{x}\rangle\langle B_{y}\rangle, (4)

with ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle defined as above, and similarly with ⟨Ax⟩=∑a,ba​P​(a,b|x,y)delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦\langle A_{x}\rangle=\sum_{a,b}a\,P(a,b|x,y) and ⟨By⟩=∑a,bb​P​(a,b|x,y)delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦subscript𝑎𝑏𝑏𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle=\sum_{a,b}b\,P(a,b|x,y) (for continuous values, the sums can simply be replaced by integrals, and the probabilities by probability density functions; note also that because of the non-signalling assumption, ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle does not depend on y𝑦y, and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle does not depend on x𝑥x). We emphasize that because of the product term in Eq. (4), the covariance is a nonlinear function of the joint probabilities P​(a,b|x,y)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦P(a,b|x,y).

We start by again considering the case of two measurements per party (x,y∈{0,1}𝑥𝑦01x,y\in\{0,1\}), but with now outcomes Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} and Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} that can take any values a,b𝑎𝑏a,b in the interval [−1,+1]11[-1,+1]; this implies in particular that −1≤cov​(Ax,By)≤11covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦1-1\leq\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})\leq 1 (note that if a,b𝑎𝑏a,b are taken in any other bounded interval, they can, together with the corresponding covariance, simply be rescaled so that they lie in [−1,+1]11[-1,+1]). Our goal is to bound the set of possible values of the four covariances cov​(Ax,By)covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y}) for local distributions—the “local set” for covariances. To get some intuition, and inspired by the form of CHSH in Eq. (3), one may look for instance at the projection of this local set onto the 2-dimensional (covCHSH,covCHSH′)covCHSHsuperscriptcovCHSH′(\text{covCHSH},\text{covCHSH}^{\prime}) plane, with

covCHSH ≡\displaystyle\equiv cov​(A0,B0)+cov​(A0,B1)covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1\displaystyle\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{0})+\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{1}) (5)
+cov​(A1,B0)−cov​(A1,B1),covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1\displaystyle+\ \text{cov}(A_{1},B_{0})-\text{cov}(A_{1},B_{1}),

and with covCHSH′superscriptcovCHSH′\text{covCHSH}^{\prime} defined similarly, except that cov​(A0,B1)covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{1}) and cov​(A1,B0)covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0\text{cov}(A_{1},B_{0}) come with minus signs.

By optimizing the values of covCHSH(′)superscriptcovCHSH′\text{covCHSH}^{(\prime)} numerically (but with reliable enough results), we obtained the local set represented in Fig. 1.

One immediately sees that contrary to the standard local polytope in the probability space, the local set in the covariance space is nonconvex, and that (unsurprisingly) it cannot be fully described by a finite number of Bell inequalities based on linear combinations of the covariances. Its full characterization thus looks much more complicated than that of the standard local polytope. Nevertheless, one can still derive some Bell inequalities for covariances that provide an outer approximation of the local set. As illustrated on Fig. 1, an example of such covariance Bell inequalities is the following:

covCHSH≤167.covCHSH167\displaystyle\text{covCHSH}\,\leq\,\frac{16}{7}\,. (6)

In order to prove that this inequality indeed holds for any local distribution, it is in fact sufficient to restrict to distributions with binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1. Those can be written as convex mixtures of finitely many deterministic (local) distributions, and one can then optimize the expression covCHSH over the corresponding weights. To take into account the constraint that these weights must be nonnegative and sum up to 111, one can introduce Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) multipliers KKT , which provide necessary conditions for a solution to be optimal. By considering decompositions onto different sets of deterministic distributions with nonzero weights, these KKT conditions simplify to a number of linear systems, which can easily be solved. The full details of the proof are given (together with an alternative approach) in Appendix A.

It is instructive to look more closely in the proof at decompositions with a given number d𝑑d of deterministic distributions with nonzero weights. First note that for d=1𝑑1d=1, i.e., for deterministic distributions, all covariances are 00, and therefore one also obtains covCHSH=0covCHSH0\text{covCHSH}=0. To obtain a nonzero value, one thus needs to consider mixtures of at least 2 distributions. For d=2𝑑2d=2, one finds that the maximal possible value is covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, obtained for instance by the distribution P2=12[(++/+−)+(−−/−+)]P_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\big{[}(++/+-)+(--/-+)\big{]} (which also gives covCHSH′=2superscriptcovCHSH′2\text{covCHSH}^{\prime}=2, see Fig. 1)—where the notation (A0​A1/B0​B1)subscript𝐴0subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0subscript𝐵1(A_{0}A_{1}/B_{0}B_{1}) denotes a strategy in which Alice and Bob deterministically output Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} and Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} for inputs x𝑥x and y𝑦y, respectively. In order to reach the local upper bound in Eq. (6), one needs to go to d=3𝑑3d=3; the distribution PO​p​t=37(++/++)+27(−+/−−)+27(−−/−+)P_{Opt}=\frac{3}{7}(++/++)+\frac{2}{7}(-+/--)+\frac{2}{7}(--/-+), for instance, gives covCHSH=167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}=\frac{16}{7} (and covCHSH′=1649superscriptcovCHSH′1649\text{covCHSH}^{\prime}=\frac{16}{49}, see Fig. 1). One thus sees that reaching a given value of covCHSH requires mixing a certain number of deterministic strategies; this is an interesting feature, which will allow one to use the covariance inequality as a shared randomness witness (see below).

One may also look at possible violations of the covariance Bell inequality (6). One finds that it can indeed detect quantum nonlocality: that is, one can obtain covCHSH>167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}>\frac{16}{7} by performing local measurements on an entangled state. For example, the quantum correlations that reach the maximal quantum value (the “Tsirelson bound” Tsirelson ) of CHSH=2​2222\sqrt{2} have vanishing marginals ⟨Ax⟩=⟨By⟩=0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦0\langle A_{x}\rangle=\langle B_{y}\rangle=0, and therefore also give covCHSH=2​2>167221672\sqrt{2}>\frac{16}{7} (point PQsubscript𝑃𝑄P_{Q} on Fig. 1). In fact, this is the largest possible quantum violation, as one can prove that all quantum correlations must satisfy the inequality

covCHSH≤2​2.covCHSH22\text{covCHSH}\leq 2\sqrt{2}\,. (7)

This is shown in Appendix B, where we also give a tighter characterization of the quantum set in terms of covariances. Note that in contrast to the local bound, marginals do not play any role in reaching the Tsirelson bound for covCHSH. Nevertheless, the nonlinearity of the Bell expression covCHSH also has interesting consequences in the quantum case. For instance, one can find two pure entangled states such that none of the states can individually violate the inequality (6), whereas a mixture of the two states can violate it; see Appendix C for details.

Note, finally, that given the range of output variables, we have |cov​(Ax,By)|≤1covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦1|\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})|\leq 1, and therefore the algebraic maximum possible value of covCHSH is 444 (just like for CHSH). This value can be reached by the non-signalling distribution known as the Popescu-Rohrlich (PR) nonlocal box PR (point PP​Rsubscript𝑃𝑃𝑅P_{PR} on Fig. 1), which again has vanishing marginals and also reaches the algebraic maximum of the CHSH expression.

Constructing other covariance Bell inequalities.—

One can follow similar ideas to the ones developed above and derive other Bell inequalities based on covariances.

In the case of ternary inputs x,y∈{0,1,2}𝑥𝑦012x,y\in\{0,1,2\} and binary outputs a,b∈{+1,−1}𝑎𝑏11a,b\in\{+1,-1\} for instance, the local set in the space of expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle is again fully characterized by CHSH-like inequalities; however, when considering the full probability space, i.e., including the marginals ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle, ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle, one gets a new inequivalent family of Bell inequalities of the form froissart ; sliwa ; CG

I3322subscript𝐼3322\displaystyle I_{3322} ≡\displaystyle\equiv ⟨A0​B0⟩+⟨A0​B1⟩+⟨A0​B2⟩+⟨A1​B0⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0\displaystyle\langle A_{0}B_{0}\rangle+\langle A_{0}B_{1}\rangle+\langle A_{0}B_{2}\rangle+\langle A_{1}B_{0}\rangle (8)
+⟨A1​B1⟩−⟨A1​B2⟩+⟨A2​B0⟩−⟨A2​B1⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵1\displaystyle\ +\langle A_{1}B_{1}\rangle-\langle A_{1}B_{2}\rangle+\langle A_{2}B_{0}\rangle-\langle A_{2}B_{1}\rangle
+⟨A0⟩+⟨A1⟩−⟨B0⟩−⟨B1⟩≤ 4.delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵14\displaystyle\quad+\langle A_{0}\rangle+\langle A_{1}\rangle-\langle B_{0}\rangle-\langle B_{1}\rangle\ \leq\ 4.\quad

Inspired by the previous example of CHSH, one may look at the local bound when the expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle are replaced by the covariances cov​(Ax,By)covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y}). Marginal terms, viewed e.g. as ⟨Ax⟩=⟨Ax​𝟙𝔹⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝟙𝔹\langle A_{x}\rangle=\langle A_{x}\openone_{B}\rangle (where 𝟙𝔹subscript𝟙𝔹\openone_{B} is the identity measurement operator for Bob, that always outputs b=1𝑏1b=1) then simply drop out, as cov​(Ax,𝟙𝔹)=𝟘covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝟙𝔹0\text{cov}(A_{x},\openone_{B})=0. We thus get the covariance Bell inequality (that allows for any outputs a,b∈[−1,+1]𝑎𝑏11a,b\in[-1,+1])

cov3322 ≡\displaystyle\equiv cov​(A0,B0)+cov​(A0,B1)+cov​(A0,B2)covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1covsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵2\displaystyle\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{0})+\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{1})+\text{cov}(A_{0},B_{2}) (9)
+cov​(A1,B0)+cov​(A1,B1)−cov​(A1,B2)covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1covsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵2\displaystyle\ +\ \text{cov}(A_{1},B_{0})+\text{cov}(A_{1},B_{1})-\text{cov}(A_{1},B_{2})
+cov​(A2,B0)−cov​(A2,B1)≤92.covsubscript𝐴2subscript𝐵0covsubscript𝐴2subscript𝐵192\displaystyle\quad+\ \text{cov}(A_{2},B_{0})-\text{cov}(A_{2},B_{1})\ \leq\ \frac{9}{2}\,.

Here the local bound was obtained through numerical optimization (up to machine precision); nevertheless, the reproducibility and reliability of the numerical results make us quite confident that the bound is correct. In Appendix D we present local distributions that reach it, and discuss quantum and super-quantum (non-signalling) violations.

More generally, one may consider constructing covariance Bell inequalities following the above recipe, starting from an arbitrary linear Bell inequality with binary outcomes. Note that instead of simply dropping the marginal terms, one could as well keep them, or replace them with other functions, e.g. with variances.

Generalising even further our approach for covariance Bell inequalities, one can also investigate Bell inequalities based on Pearson correlators, which can be thought of as normalised covariances. The Pearson correlator for two variables Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} and Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} with variances σ​(Ax)2=⟨Ax2⟩−⟨Ax⟩2𝜎superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑥2delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑥2superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥2\sigma(A_{x})^{2}=\langle A_{x}^{2}\rangle-\langle A_{x}\rangle^{2} and σ​(By)2=⟨By2⟩−⟨By⟩2𝜎superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑦2delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑦2superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦2\sigma(B_{y})^{2}=\langle B_{y}^{2}\rangle-\langle B_{y}\rangle^{2} is defined as r​(Ax,By)=cov​(Ax,By)σ​(Ax)​σ​(By)rsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦\text{r}(A_{x},B_{y})=\frac{\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})}{\sigma(A_{x})\sigma(B_{y})} (if either σ​(Ax)𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥\sigma(A_{x}) or σ​(By)𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦\sigma(B_{y}) is zero, we define r​(Ax,By)=0rsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦0\text{r}(A_{x},B_{y})=0). Following a similar construction as above, we get, for the case of binary inputs and now also restricting to binary outputs, the Bell inequality

rCHSH ≡\displaystyle\equiv r​(A0,B0)+r​(A0,B1)rsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0rsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1\displaystyle\text{r}(A_{0},B_{0})+\text{r}(A_{0},B_{1}) (10)
+r​(A1,B0)−r​(A1,B1)≤52,rsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0rsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵152\displaystyle+\ \text{r}(A_{1},B_{0})-\text{r}(A_{1},B_{1})\ \leq\ \frac{5}{2},

where the local bound was again obtained through numerical optimization. It must be emphasized that unlike for covariances, the local set for Pearson correlators is not the same when considering binary outputs or more possible outputs; for instance, with ternary outputs in {+1,0,−1}101\{+1,0,-1\}, one can locally reach the value rCHSH=2​2rCHSH22\text{rCHSH}=2\sqrt{2}, which turns out to also be the Tsirelson bound for rCHSH (whether we restrict to binary outputs or not), as proven already in Ref. landau (we also give a proof of this in Appendix B). In Appendix D we present local distributions that reach these two local bounds of 5252\frac{5}{2} and 2​2222\sqrt{2}, and discuss quantum and super-quantum violations of them. Of course, similar Bell inequalities with Pearson correlators could also be constructed, following a similar recipe as suggested above, starting e.g. from I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322} or any other linear Bell inequality with binary outcomes.

Shared randomness witnesses.—

Let us come back now to covCHSH. As emphasized before, the value of covCHSH that can be obtained locally depends on the number of deterministic strategies involved in the local strategy being used. This readily allows one to obtain a lower bound on the classical dimension d𝑑d of the shared variable ΛΛ\Lambda (i.e., the number of different values it can take), or equivalently its max-entropy Hmax​(Λ)≡log2⁡dsubscript𝐻maxΛsubscript2𝑑H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\equiv\log_{2}d: from the discussion above, it follows that as soon as covCHSH>0covCHSH0\text{covCHSH}>0, one requires d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, i.e. Hmax​(Λ)≥1subscript𝐻maxΛ1H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\geq 1; if covCHSH>2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}>2, then d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3, i.e. Hmax​(Λ)≥log2⁡3subscript𝐻maxΛsubscript23H_{\text{max}}(\Lambda)\geq\log_{2}3.

One may also quantify the amount of shared randomness in terms of the Shannon entropy of ΛΛ\Lambda, H​(Λ)≡−∑λqλ​log2⁡qλ𝐻Λsubscript𝜆subscript𝑞𝜆subscript2subscript𝑞𝜆H(\Lambda)\equiv-\sum_{\lambda}q_{\lambda}\log_{2}q_{\lambda} (defined here, for simplicity, for the case of a discrete variable ΛΛ\Lambda that takes the value λ𝜆\lambda with probability P​(Λ=λ)=qλ𝑃Λ𝜆subscript𝑞𝜆P(\Lambda=\lambda)=q_{\lambda}). For a given value of covCHSH between 00 and 167167\frac{16}{7}, one can also obtain a lower bound on H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda) by minimizing it for all local strategies. As it turns out, it suffices to optimise H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda) over decompositions onto deterministic strategies with binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1—intuitively, local randomness does not help increase covCHSH. The details of our optimization are given in Appendix E, and the results we obtained are plotted on Fig. 2. Unsurprisingly, we find that min⁡H​(Λ)𝐻Λ\min H(\Lambda) increases with the value of covCHSH. As soon as covCHSH>0covCHSH0\text{covCHSH}>0, one requires H​(Λ)>0𝐻Λ0H(\Lambda)>0; for covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, one must have H​(Λ)≥1𝐻Λ1H(\Lambda)\geq 1 (recall that covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2 can be reached by mixing two deterministic strategies with equal weights); finally, reaching the local bound of covCHSH=167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}=\frac{16}{7} requires at least as much shared randomness as in the distribution PO​p​tsubscript𝑃𝑂𝑝𝑡P_{Opt} given previously, i.e. H​(Λ)≥−37​log2⁡37−2×27​log2⁡27≃1.56𝐻Λ37subscript237227subscript227similar-to-or-equals1.56H(\Lambda)\geq-\frac{3}{7}\log_{2}\frac{3}{7}-2\!\times\!\frac{2}{7}\log_{2}\frac{2}{7}\simeq 1.56.

Thus covCHSH acts as a device-independent witness for characterizing the dimension and the entropy of the shared randomness of a local strategy in a Bell experiment. This complements recent works on device-independent tests of the dimension of quantum systems dimH , and of the dimension gallego and entropy CBB of classical communications.

Discussion.—

In this Letter we introduced Bell inequalities based on covariances, a natural measure of correlations, rather than on linear combinations of probabilities. We presented the simplest example of such a covariance Bell inequality with binary inputs, that echoes the well-known CHSH inequality, and investigated some of its properties. Proving analytically the local bound is not straightforward here, due to the nonlinearity of the Bell expression, but we could nevertheless provide a method to do so. Its quantum bound was also proven analytically.

Beyond this simplest example, we proposed a general recipe to construct, from any standard Bell inequality with binary outcomes, new Bell inequalities for covariances as well as for Pearson correlators. While our analytical method for proving the local bound generalizes in principle to any covariance Bell inequality obtained with our construction, in practice it becomes intractable for larger numbers of inputs. Nevertheless, for the examples we presented the local bounds could reliably be obtained numerically. It would be interesting to find a more efficient way to prove local bounds, as well as quantum bounds, for covariance-based Bell inequalities—or even to find other ways to characterize the local and quantum sets of admissible covariances (note that a tighter characterization of the quantum set than Eq. (7) can already be given, see Appendix B). One possible idea would be to look for some hierarchy of criteria—similar in spirit to that of Navascués-Pironio-Acín (NPA) for quantum correlations—that covariances must satisfy; indeed, one finds that covariances and Pearson correlators appear naturally in the NPA hierarchy NPA .

An interesting feature of our covariance Bell inequalities is that they serve as a shared randomness witness. Indeed, in contrast with standard linear Bell inequalities where the local bound can always be attained by a single deterministic strategy, reaching the local bound—or in fact, any nontrivial value—for a Bell expression defined in terms of covariances requires, for a local strategy, to make use of shared randomness. We showed explicitly, on our simplest example, how the value of the Bell expression allows one to place device-independent lower bounds on the amount of shared randomness in a local model (both in terms of its dimension and its entropy). Such witnesses may help addressing certain problems in quantum nonlocality related to shared randomness pal ; sikora ; vicente , in particular finding what is the minimal amount of shared randomness necessary to simulate the correlations of entangled states admitting a local model joe . Our example with binary inputs allows one to certify the use of relatively little shared randomness (e.g. a dimension of at least 333); it would be interesting to find (families of) covariance Bell inequalities that can certify larger amounts of shared randomness. While covariance Bell inequalities were found to provide a natural way to provide device-independent witnesses for shared randomness, such witnesses could also be studied in other frameworks, with other types of Bell inequalities that require shared randomness to be saturated—e.g. with entropic inequalities bc ; cerf ; chaves .

From a more practical perspective, our covariance Bell inequality could be useful in experimental situations where access to measurement data is limited, e.g. if only covariances can be measured, and where standard Bell inequalities cannot be used. This could be relevant to certain mesoscopic electronics experimental setups. With such applications in mind, it would also be interesting to also investigate similar covariance inequalities to the ones constructed here for other types of quantum nonlocality, e.g. for entanglement HHHH or quantum steering steering (we note that inequalities were constructed in these contexts for covariance matrices, although following very different approaches WW ; giedke ; guehne ; jevtic ; maccone ).

Finally, Bell inequalities based on covariances could be useful for the study of nonlocal correlations in networks. When a network features several sources that are assumed to be independent, the set of local distributions (or rather, “N𝑁N-local distributions” for a network with N𝑁N independent sources) is typically nonconvex, and nonlinear Bell inequalities are necessary to give an effective description of the (N𝑁N-)local set branciard ; biloc2 ; armin ; chaves16 ; rosset16 . In fact, some recent work chaves17 has already made use of covariances in the context of quantum networks, however not constructing explicit Bell inequalities. The ideas developed here could also find some nice applications in providing ways to obtain new types of Bell inequalities, and possibly shared randomness witnesses, for networks.

Appendix A Proofs of the covariance Bell inequality (6)

Obtaining the local bound for a standard (linear) Bell inequality is rather straightforward, as one can simply focus on deterministic strategies. However, such an approach does not work for covariance Bell inequalities because of their nonlinearity.

In this Appendix we give the details of the proof of the inequality (6), as sketched in the main text. We then present an alternative proof that also uses Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) multipliers and conditions KKT , although in a different way. While the former can in principle be adapted to any other covariance Bell inequality (but may not actually be practical because of the very high number of cases to consider for increased numbers of parameters), the latter exploits specific properties of the CHSH (2-input / 2-output) scenario and uses fewer variables in the optimization; it is however less instructive with respect to the shared randomness required for obtaining a given value of covCHSH with a local model, and adapting it to another scenario will first require finding the right properties to exploit.

A.1 Optimizing over the weights of deterministic distributions

The proof here will be divided into three parts. The first one consists in showing that, without loss of generality, we can focus on a situation where only binary outputs are considered. The second part describes how standard methods for solving (quadratic) constrained problems can be applied. Finally, the third part shows how our quadratic problem can be simplified to a number of linear ones, and solved.

A.1.1 Reduction to binary outputs

Consider a local distribution P​(a,b|x,y)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦P(a,b|x,y) with outputs a,b∈[−1,+1]𝑎𝑏11a,b\in[-1,+1].222Note that given the translational invariance of covariances (i.e., cov​(Ax,By)=cov​(Ax+α,By+β)covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦covsubscript𝐴𝑥𝛼subscript𝐵𝑦𝛽\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y})=\text{cov}(A_{x}+\alpha,B_{y}+\beta) for any real values α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta), it would be equivalent to take a,b𝑎𝑏a,b in any interval of length 222. Similarly in the case of binary outputs, instead of ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 one could take any two real values with a difference of 222. Let then Alice and Bob post-process their outputs locally, in the following way: they replace each output a𝑎a (b𝑏b) by a′=+1superscript𝑎′1a^{\prime}=+1 (b′=+1superscript𝑏′1b^{\prime}=+1) with probability 1+a21𝑎2\frac{1+a}{2} (1+b21𝑏2\frac{1+b}{2}), or by a′=−1superscript𝑎′1a^{\prime}=-1 (b′=−1superscript𝑏′1b^{\prime}=-1) with probability 1−a21𝑎2\frac{1-a}{2} (1−b21𝑏2\frac{1-b}{2}), thus defining a new local distribution P′​(a′,b′|x,y)=∑a​b1+a′​a2​1+b′​b2​P​(a,b|x,y)superscript𝑃′superscript𝑎′conditionalsuperscript𝑏′𝑥𝑦subscript𝑎𝑏1superscript𝑎′𝑎21superscript𝑏′𝑏2𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦P^{\prime}(a^{\prime},b^{\prime}|x,y)=\sum_{ab}\frac{1+a^{\prime}a}{2}\frac{1+b^{\prime}b}{2}P(a,b|x,y) with binary outputs a′,b′∈{+1,−1}superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′11a^{\prime},b^{\prime}\in\{+1,-1\}. This is why one does not obtain the same local bound on rCHSH when considering binary outputs or a larger set of possible outputs; see Appendix D.2.

Thus, any values of the covariances cov​(Ax,By)covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y}) (for the various inputs x,y𝑥𝑦x,y) obtained by a local distribution with inputs in [−1,+1]11[-1,+1] can also be obtained by a local distribution with inputs in {+1,−1}11\{+1,-1\} (and vice-versa, obviously). The local set for covariances is the same in both cases, and to characterize it it thus suffices to restrict to local distributions with binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1.

Given the regularity of the problem, with the constraints being affine functions of the variables, the (local) maxima must then necessarily fulfill the KKT conditions KKT :

∂L∂qk=Ck​k−∑iqi​(Ci​k+Ck​i)+λk−μ=0∀k,formulae-sequence𝐿subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘𝑖subscript𝜆𝑘𝜇0for-all𝑘\displaystyle\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{k}}=C_{kk}-\sum_{i}q_{i}(C_{ik}+C_{ki})+\lambda_{k}-\mu=0\quad\forall k,
∂L∂μ=1−∑kqk=0,𝐿𝜇1subscript𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘0\displaystyle\frac{\partial L}{\partial\mu}=1-\sum_{k}q_{k}=0,
λk​qk=0,λk≥0,qk≥0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑘0subscript𝑞𝑘0\displaystyle\lambda_{k}q_{k}=0,\;\lambda_{k}\geq 0,\;q_{k}\geq 0. (13)

A.1.3 Reduction to linear systems of equations and resolution

Because of the constraint λk​qk=0subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘0\lambda_{k}q_{k}=0, the above system of equations is nonlinear. One can however reduce it to a number of different linear systems of equations by imposing that a given subset of weigths qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} take nonzero values, and by considering separately the case of each possible subset. For those qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} in the given subset under consideration, the last line of Eq. (A.1.2) simply becomes λk=0,qk>0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑘0subscript𝑞𝑘0\lambda_{k}=0,q_{k}>0, while for the other qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}’s, it becomes qk=0,λk≥0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑘0subscript𝜆𝑘0q_{k}=0,\lambda_{k}\geq 0—with in both cases, λk=−Ck​k+∑iqi​(Ci​k+Ck​i)+μsubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘𝑖𝜇\lambda_{k}=-C_{kk}+\sum_{i}q_{i}(C_{ik}+C_{ki})+\mu according to the first line of Eq. (A.1.2). For a given number d𝑑d of nonzero weights, the system (A.1.2) then reduces to d+1𝑑1d+1 linear equality constraints and 161616 (also linear) inequality constraints (with d𝑑d strict and 16−d16𝑑16-d nonstrict inequalities) for the remaining d+1𝑑1d+1 nontrivial variables qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} and μ𝜇\mu.

Note that if only d=1𝑑1d=1 weight qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} is nonzero (and therefore equal to 1), then the distribution P​(a,b|x,y)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦P(a,b|x,y) is deterministic, which implies that all covariances—and hence covCHSH—are zero. Furthermore, as already mentioned previously, due to Carathéodory’s theorem it is sufficient to only consider subsets with at most d=9𝑑9d=9 (out of 161616) nonzero qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}’s—indeed, if a maximum is reached by some decomposition involving more than 999 deterministic distributions, then it is also reached by another decomposition giving the same distribution, but involving no more than 999 deterministic distributions. We used Mathematica to solve, for each value of d𝑑d between 222 and 999, the (16d)binomial16𝑑\binom{16}{d} different linear systems of equations corresponding to all the different subsets containing d𝑑d nonzero weights (which makes a total of ∑d=29(16d)=50 626superscriptsubscript𝑑29binomial16𝑑50626\sum_{d=2}^{9}\binom{16}{d}=50\,626 linear systems to consider). More specifically, we first found the solutions that satisfy all equality constraints and then checked which ones also satisfy the inequality constraints. To obtain the local bound of our covariance Bell inequality (6), there then remains to check what is the largest possible value of covCHSH for all these feasible solutions.

For d=2𝑑2d=2, all (162)=120binomial162120\binom{16}{2}=120 systems of equations have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints (out of which, 565656 have unique solutions and 646464 are still underdetermined), but only 444 out of them have (unique) solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. Those 444 solutions all give covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, which is the maximal value that one can reach by mixing only 222 local deterministic distributions.

With d=3𝑑3d=3 nonzero weights qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}, again all (163)=560binomial163560\binom{16}{3}=560 systems of equations have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints (432432432 with unique solutions and 128128128 still underdetermined), but only 888 of them have (unique) solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. Those solutions are listed in Table 1; they all have the similar form P=37​Pk1det+27​Pk2det+27​Pk3det𝑃37superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘1det27superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘2det27superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘3detP=\frac{3}{7}P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{2}{7}P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{2}{7}P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}, and all give the value covCHSH=167covCHSH167\text{covCHSH}=\frac{16}{7}.

As it turns out, this value of 167167\frac{16}{7} obtained by suitably mixing 3 deterministic local distributions cannot be increased by mixing more distributions. For d=4𝑑4d=4 for instance, we find that out of the (164)=1 820binomial1641820\binom{16}{4}=1\,820 systems of equations, only 1 51615161\,516 have solutions that satisfy all equality constraints, out of which only 141414 have solutions that also satisfy the inequality constraints. 666 of these (still underdetermined) solutions give a local maximum of covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, while the other 888 (unique) solutions—all of the form P=38​Pk1det+38​Pk2det+18​Pk3det+18​Pk4det𝑃38superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘1det38superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘2det18superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘3det18superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘4detP=\frac{3}{8}P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{3}{8}P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{8}P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{8}P_{k_{4}}^{\text{det}} (one solution being obtained for instance by taking Pk1det=(++/++),Pk2det=(−+/−−),Pk3det=(+−/−+)P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}=(++/++),P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}=(-+/--),P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}=(+-/-+) and Pk4det=(−−/−+)P_{k_{4}}^{\text{det}}=(--/-+))—give covCHSH=94covCHSH94\text{covCHSH}=\frac{9}{4}. The results for all values of d𝑑d from 222 to 999 are summarized in Table 2. For d=6𝑑6d=6 and 888, we also get local maxima of covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2, while for d=5,7𝑑57d=5,7 and 999, no solutions are found for any of the corresponding systems of KKT conditions. As one can see, the maximal value of covCHSH obtained for all cases is thus 167167\frac{16}{7}; this concludes the proof that this is indeed the value of the local bound in our covariance Bell inequality (6).

It should be clarified that although Table 2 gives local maxima of 222 or 9494\frac{9}{4} for d≥4𝑑4d\geq 4, this does not mean that those are the maximum values of covCHSH when mixing d≥4𝑑4d\geq 4 deterministic local distributions. Indeed, the table gives local maxima obtained in a set delimited by strict inequalities qk>0subscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}>0, while the suprema over these sets may be obtained for some qk→0→subscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}\to 0. In fact, covCHSH can get arbitrarily close to 167167\frac{16}{7} with a mixture of d≥4𝑑4d\geq 4 deterministic local distributions by mixing an optimal decomposition with 333 distributions from Table 1, with a tiny amount of d−3𝑑3d-3 other distributions.

Another observation of interest is that all solutions of the KKT conditions that give a local maximum value of covCHSH=2covCHSH2\text{covCHSH}=2 (for d=2,4,6,8𝑑2468d=2,4,6,8, as listed in the table) are of the general form P=q1′[(++/++)+(−−/−−)]+q2′[(++/+−)+(−−/−+)]+q3′[(+−/++)+(−+/−−)]+q4′[(+−/−+)+(−+/+−)]P=q_{1}^{\prime}\big{[}(++/++)+(--/--)\big{]}+q_{2}^{\prime}\big{[}(++/+-)+(--/-+)\big{]}+q_{3}^{\prime}\big{[}(+-/++)+(-+/--)\big{]}+q_{4}^{\prime}\big{[}(+-/-+)+(-+/+-)\big{]} with q1′,q2′,q3′,q4′≥0superscriptsubscript𝑞1′superscriptsubscript𝑞2′superscriptsubscript𝑞3′superscriptsubscript𝑞4′0q_{1}^{\prime},q_{2}^{\prime},q_{3}^{\prime},q_{4}^{\prime}\geq 0 and 2​(q1′+q2′+q3′+q4′)=12superscriptsubscript𝑞1′superscriptsubscript𝑞2′superscriptsubscript𝑞3′superscriptsubscript𝑞4′12(q_{1}^{\prime}+q_{2}^{\prime}+q_{3}^{\prime}+q_{4}^{\prime})=1: for d=2𝑑2d=2, three of the coefficients qk′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘′q_{k}^{\prime} are zero (which, for each remaining nonzero qk′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘′q_{k}^{\prime}, gives a unique solution to the corresponding system of equations); for d=4𝑑4d=4, two of the coefficients qk′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘′q_{k}^{\prime} are zero; for d=6𝑑6d=6, one of the coefficients qk′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘′q_{k}^{\prime} is zero; and for d=8𝑑8d=8, all coefficients qk′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘′q_{k}^{\prime} are nonzero (which indeed makes the solutions in these last 3 cases underdetermined). As one can see, in this general decomposition each deterministic distribution comes with its “opposite”, in which all outputs are flipped, with the same weight. This implies in particular that all marginal expectation values ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle are zero, that the covariances cov​(Ax,By)covsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\text{cov}(A_{x},B_{y}) are equal to the expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, and therefore that the expression of covCHSH simply reduces to that of CHSH (i.e., the nonlinear part vanishes)—which is indeed bounded by 222 for local distributions. This highlights the crucial role played by the nonlinear terms ⟨Ax⟩​⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}\rangle\langle B_{y}\rangle in covCHSH: these are precisely the terms that allow the local bound of covCHSH to be greater than that of CHSH; and in order to reach a value of covCHSH larger than 2 with a local distribution, one needs at least one pair of settings x,y𝑥𝑦x,y for which ⟨Ax⟩​⟨By⟩≠0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦0\langle A_{x}\rangle\langle B_{y}\rangle\neq 0.

A.2 Optimizing over the expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle

We now present a second possible approach for the proof of Eq. (6), which builds on the observation that the local bound 167167\frac{16}{7} on covCHSH follows from just imposing the local bound 222 on CHSH (which must be respected by any local distribution), and that probabilities are nonnegative. More precisely, as previously we note that one can restrict to binary outputs a,b=±1𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1a,b=\pm 1; as it turns out, it will then suffice to impose, together with CHSH≤2CHSH2\text{CHSH}\leq 2, that P​(a,b|x,y)≥0𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦0P(a,b|x,y)\geq 0 for all x,y,a,b𝑥𝑦𝑎𝑏x,y,a,b satisfying a​b=(−1)x​y+1𝑎𝑏superscript1𝑥𝑦1ab=(-1)^{xy+1}.

Instead of writing covCHSH as a function of the weights of deterministic distributions in a local decomposition, here we will view it directly as a function of the expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle. Our goal is thus to maximize the value of covCHSH under the above constraints—which can also all be expressed in terms of those expectation values, by writing in particular P​(a,b|x,y)=14​(1+a​⟨Ax⟩+b​⟨By⟩+a​b​⟨Ax​By⟩)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦141𝑎delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥𝑏delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦𝑎𝑏delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦P(a,b|x,y)=\frac{1}{4}(1+a\langle A_{x}\rangle+b\langle B_{y}\rangle+ab\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle).

The first 3 lines define 8 linear equality constraints for the 8 multipliers λx​y​a​bsubscript𝜆𝑥𝑦𝑎𝑏\lambda_{xyab}, which can be solved and give

with x¯=1−x¯𝑥1𝑥{\bar{x}}=1-x and y¯=1−y¯𝑦1𝑦{\bar{y}}=1-y. We can then consider the 21+8=512superscript2185122^{1+8}=512 corresponding cases separately, and solve for each case the resulting linear system of 9 equations for the 9 variables ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle, ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle and λ𝜆\lambda.

Using Mathematica we found feasible solutions for those equations in 320320320 of the 512512512 cases. However, one still needs to check if these solutions satisfy the remaining inequality constraints in Eq. (15); only in 207207207 of those cases could we find solutions that indeed satisfy all KKT conditions. Among all these solutions, we found that the maximal value of covCHSH was 167167\frac{16}{7}, which again proves that this is the local bound of our covariance Bell inequality (6). This value of 167167\frac{16}{7} was obtained for the 888 solutions listed in Table 3, which indeed define the same 888 distributions as those listed (in the same order) in Table 1.

A.3 Generalizing our proofs to other covariance Bell inequalities

The two versions of the proof of inequality (6) presented above could in principle be generalized to calculate the local bound of any covariance Bell inequality constructed from a linear Bell inequality with binary outcomes, following the recipe we suggest in the main text. However, as the number of inputs, and therefore the dimension of the relevant probability space, increase, the number of different cases to consider in the proof may become too large to be tractable in a reasonable time.

For the case of cov3322 with ternary inputs for instance, after reducing to binary outputs and taking into account normalization and non-signalling constraints, the relevant probability space is of dimension dimP→=15subscriptdim→𝑃15\text{dim}_{\vec{P}}=15. Following the first approach for the proof above, local distributions can be decomposed onto the 26superscript262^{6} deterministic local distributions, and the number of different cases to consider (corresponding to the number of subsets of d𝑑d nonzero weights qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}, with 2≤d≤dimP→+12𝑑subscriptdim→𝑃12\leq d\leq\text{dim}_{\vec{P}}+1) is ∑d=216(26d)≥7×1014superscriptsubscript𝑑216binomialsuperscript26𝑑7superscript1014\sum_{d=2}^{16}\binom{2^{6}}{d}\geq 7\times 10^{14}, a number far too large for all cases to be considered separately.

One may hope that following our second approach for the proof, instead, may reduce the number of cases to be considered down to a tractable one. The first thing to check here would be which constraints (locality constraints in terms of CHSH or I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322} inequalities, together with non-negativity of the probabilities constraints) are sufficient to impose in order to obtain the local bound on cov3322. We did not follow this approach any further, and leave as an open question, whether this would be tractable enough to provide an analytical proof of inequality (9).

Instead, to obtain the local bound of inequality (9), we resorted to numerical optimization, by optimizing over the 26=64superscript26642^{6}=64 weights qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} in a local decomposition of P=∑kqk​Pkdet𝑃subscript𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘detP=\sum_{k}q_{k}P_{k}^{\text{det}}. Although the optimization problem is nonconvex and involves quite a few free parameters, we found that the result of the numerical optimization was stable enough when starting from different starting points, which makes us confident that the local bound of 9292\frac{9}{2} in inequality (9) is indeed correct.

We note, finally, that the same proof techniques as above do not work for Bell inequalities with Pearson correlators like inequality (10). The first point to be noticed is that, as emphasized before, the local sets for binary outputs a,b∈{+1,−1}𝑎𝑏11a,b\in\{+1,-1\} and for more outputs a,b∈[−1,+1]𝑎𝑏11a,b\in[-1,+1] are not the same—indeed we found different local bounds for binary and ternary outputs. Even restricting to a fixed number of inputs and trying to follow our approach with KKT multipliers, the Lagrangians we would write in either of the two proof versions would not be nicely quadratic functions of the weights qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} in a local decomposition of the form P=∑qk​Pkdet𝑃subscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘detP=\sum q_{k}P_{k}^{\text{det}} (as in Eq. (A.1.2)), or of the expectation values ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle, ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle (as in Eq. (A.2)), so that the KKT necessary conditions for linearity would not simplify to linear systems of equations. Instead of pursuing such an approach, we again resorted here to numerical optimizations. As before, the numerical results we obtained were stable enough to make us confident that the local bounds we give are correct.

Appendix B Tsirelson bounds and quantum violations for covCHSH and rCHSH

In this Appendix we give the proofs that the Tsirelson bounds for both covCHSH and rCHSH are the same as for CHSH, namely 2​2222\sqrt{2}. The proofs presented here are inspired by that of Landau (for rCHSH) in Ref. landau .

B.1 Tsirelson bound for covCHSH

First note that by Neumark’s dilation theorem, any quantum correlation can be obtained by projective measurements on pure states in Hilbert spaces of large enough dimensions.

B.2 Tsirelson bound for rCHSH

To obtain the Tsirelson bound for rCHSH, we follow a very similar approach to the one above, considering now normalized ket vectors |α~x⟩=|αx⟩/‖|αx⟩‖ketsubscript~𝛼𝑥ketsubscript𝛼𝑥normketsubscript𝛼𝑥\left|\tilde{\alpha}_{x}\right\rangle=\left|\alpha_{x}\right\rangle\!/|\!|\!\left|\alpha_{x}\right\rangle\!|\!| and |β~y⟩=|βy⟩/‖|βy⟩‖ketsubscript~𝛽𝑦ketsubscript𝛽𝑦normketsubscript𝛽𝑦\left|\tilde{\beta}_{y}\right\rangle=\left|\beta_{y}\right\rangle\!/|\!|\!\left|\beta_{y}\right\rangle\!|\!| (if |αx⟩ketsubscript𝛼𝑥\left|\alpha_{x}\right\rangle or |βy⟩ketsubscript𝛽𝑦\left|\beta_{y}\right\rangle are null vectors, we define |α~x⟩ketsubscript~𝛼𝑥\left|\tilde{\alpha}_{x}\right\rangle or |β~y⟩ketsubscript~𝛽𝑦\left|\tilde{\beta}_{y}\right\rangle to be any unit vector orthogonal to all other ones). With these, we now have

⟨α~x|β~y⟩=r​(Ax,By).inner-productsubscript~𝛼𝑥subscript~𝛽𝑦rsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\displaystyle\left\langle\tilde{\alpha}_{x}\middle|\tilde{\beta}_{y}\right\rangle=\text{r}(A_{x},B_{y}). (28)

Because of the normalization of |α~x⟩,|β~y⟩ketsubscript~𝛼𝑥ketsubscript~𝛽𝑦\left|\tilde{\alpha}_{x}\right\rangle,\left|\tilde{\beta}_{y}\right\rangle and r​(Ax,By)rsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\text{r}(A_{x},B_{y}) (via the division by the variances σ​(Ax),σ​(By)𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦\sigma(A_{x}),\sigma(B_{y})), we do not need to restrict here to measurement operators with eigenvalues in [−1,+1]11[-1,+1] (or such that σ​(Ax),σ​(By)≤1𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦1\sigma(A_{x}),\sigma(B_{y})\leq 1). With the same calculations as in Eq. (20), we obtain, for any choice of (bounded) measurement operators A^x,B^ysubscript^𝐴𝑥subscript^𝐵𝑦\hat{A}_{x},\hat{B}_{y},

rCHSH =\displaystyle= ⟨α~0|β~0⟩+⟨α~0|β~1⟩+⟨α~1|β~0⟩−⟨α~1|β~1⟩inner-productsubscript~𝛼0subscript~𝛽0inner-productsubscript~𝛼0subscript~𝛽1inner-productsubscript~𝛼1subscript~𝛽0inner-productsubscript~𝛼1subscript~𝛽1\displaystyle\left\langle\tilde{\alpha}_{0}\middle|\tilde{\beta}_{0}\right\rangle+\left\langle\tilde{\alpha}_{0}\middle|\tilde{\beta}_{1}\right\rangle+\left\langle\tilde{\alpha}_{1}\middle|\tilde{\beta}_{0}\right\rangle-\left\langle\tilde{\alpha}_{1}\middle|\tilde{\beta}_{1}\right\rangle (29)
≤⋯≤ 2​2.absent⋯22\displaystyle\leq\ \cdots\ \leq\ 2\sqrt{2}.

This bound can again be reached quantum mechanically, see below.

As just mentioned, here no restriction is imposed on the measurement outcomes (provided only that σ​(Ax),σ​(By)<∞𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦\sigma(A_{x}),\sigma(B_{y})<\infty). The bound above also holds for local distributions (which can always be realized quantum mechanically) when measurement outcomes are not necessarily restricted to be binary; as we show explicitly in Appendix D.2.2, it can also be reached locally with ternary outcomes. It is quite remarkable that the local and the Tsirelson bounds coincide in this case.

Let us finally mention again that, as it was done in Ref. landau (see also Ref. NPA ), a tighter characterization of the quantum set in terms of Pearson correlators can also be given: any quantum correlation satisfies

arcsin⁡r​(A0,B0)+arcsin⁡r​(A0,B1)rsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0rsubscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1\displaystyle\arcsin\text{r}(A_{0},B_{0})+\arcsin\text{r}(A_{0},B_{1})
+arcsin⁡r​(A1,B0)−arcsin⁡r​(A1,B1)≤πrsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0rsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1𝜋\displaystyle\ +\ \arcsin\text{r}(A_{1},B_{0})-\arcsin\text{r}(A_{1},B_{1})\ \leq\ \pi (30)

(as well as the symmetrical inequalities).

B.3 Explicit quantum violations of inequalities (6) and (10)

The Tsirelson bounds for covCHSH and rCHSH can be reached by the same quantum mechanical correlations as those that reach the maximal quantum value of CHSH=2​2CHSH22\text{CHSH}=2\sqrt{2}. For instance, consider that Alice and Bob share a two-qubit maximally entangled state |ϕ+⟩=12​(|0,0⟩+|1,1⟩)ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ12ket00ket11\left|\phi_{+}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\left|0,0\right\rangle+\left|1,1\right\rangle) and perform the local measurements A^0=σ^z,A^1=σ^x,B^0=σ^z+σ^x2formulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴0subscript^𝜎zformulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴1subscript^𝜎xsubscript^𝐵0subscript^𝜎zsubscript^𝜎x2\hat{A}_{0}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}},\hat{A}_{1}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}},\hat{B}_{0}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}+\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}}{\sqrt{2}} and B^1=σ^z−σ^x2subscript^𝐵1subscript^𝜎zsubscript^𝜎x2\hat{B}_{1}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}-\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}}{\sqrt{2}}, where σ^zsubscript^𝜎z\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}} and σ^xsubscript^𝜎x\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}} denote the Pauli matrices. In that case the marginal expectation values ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle vanish, so that covCHSH and rCHSH simply reduce to CHSH, and we indeed obtain covCHSH = rCHSH = CHSH = 2​2222\sqrt{2}.

By then rotating for instance Bob’s measurement settings together around the y𝑦y axis of the Bloch sphere, one obtains the full circle drawn on Fig. 1.

Appendix C Higher quantum violations of Ineq. (6) with mixed states: a consequence of nonlinearity

In this Appendix we discuss an example illustrating the fact that the nonlinearity of the Bell inequality (6) has nontrivial consequences also in the quantum case. Specifically, consider two pure entangled states of the form

|ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\displaystyle\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle =\displaystyle= cos⁡θ2​|0,0⟩+sin⁡θ2​|1,1⟩,𝜃2ket00𝜃2ket11\displaystyle\cos{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}\left|0,0\right\rangle+\sin{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}\left|1,1\right\rangle, (31)
|ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\displaystyle\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle =\displaystyle= sin⁡θ2​|0,0⟩+cos⁡θ2​|1,1⟩,𝜃2ket00𝜃2ket11\displaystyle\sin{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}\left|0,0\right\rangle+\cos{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}\left|1,1\right\rangle, (32)

with θ∈]0,π/2]\theta\in\ ]0,\pi/2], and let us then define the equal mixture of these states:

ρθ=12​(|ϕθ⟩​⟨ϕθ|+|ϕθ⟩​⟨ϕθ|).subscript𝜌𝜃12ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃brasubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃brasubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\displaystyle\rho_{\theta}=\frac{1}{2}(\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle\!\left\langle\phi_{\theta}\right|+\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle\!\left\langle\phi_{\theta}\right|)\,. (33)

We numerically estimated the largest value of the Bell expression (5), optimizing over all local qubit measurements (including positive-operator valued measures) by Alice and Bob, for various values of the parameter θ𝜃\theta. The result is presented in Fig. 3.

We found, up to numerical precision, that for the states |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle and |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle the value of covCHSH was maximal when using the Pauli measurements A^0=σ^x,A^1=σ^y,B^0=σ^x−σ^y2formulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴0subscript^𝜎xformulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴1subscript^𝜎ysubscript^𝐵0subscript^𝜎xsubscript^𝜎y2\hat{A}_{0}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}},\hat{A}_{1}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{y}},\hat{B}_{0}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}-\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{y}}}{\sqrt{2}} and B^1=σ^x+σ^y2subscript^𝐵1subscript^𝜎xsubscript^𝜎y2\hat{B}_{1}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}+\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{y}}}{\sqrt{2}}, giving covCHSH=2​2​sin⁡θcovCHSH22𝜃\text{covCHSH}=2\sqrt{2}\sin\theta (orange dashed curve on Fig. 3), while the optimal measurements on the state ρθsubscript𝜌𝜃\rho_{\theta} were found to be A^0=σ^z,A^1=σ^x,B^0=σ^z+sin⁡θ​σ^x1+sin2⁡θformulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴0subscript^𝜎zformulae-sequencesubscript^𝐴1subscript^𝜎xsubscript^𝐵0subscript^𝜎z𝜃subscript^𝜎x1superscript2𝜃\hat{A}_{0}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}},\hat{A}_{1}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}},\hat{B}_{0}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}+\sin\theta\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}}{\sqrt{1+\sin^{2}\theta}} and B^1=σ^z−sin⁡θ​σ^x1+sin2⁡θsubscript^𝐵1subscript^𝜎z𝜃subscript^𝜎x1superscript2𝜃\hat{B}_{1}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}-\sin\theta\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}}{\sqrt{1+\sin^{2}\theta}}, giving covCHSH=2​1+sin2⁡θcovCHSH21superscript2𝜃\text{covCHSH}=2\sqrt{1+\sin^{2}\theta} (blue curve on Fig. 3). This gives violations of inequality (6) for θ>arcsin⁡16/72​2≃0.94𝜃16722similar-to-or-equals0.94\theta>\arcsin\frac{16/7}{2\sqrt{2}}\simeq 0.94 in the first case, and for θ>arcsin⁡(16/72)2−1≃0.59𝜃superscript167221similar-to-or-equals0.59\theta>\arcsin\sqrt{(\frac{16/7}{2})^{2}-1}\simeq 0.59 in the second case. We thus find that in the range of parameters 0.59≲θ≲0.94less-than-or-similar-to0.59𝜃less-than-or-similar-to0.940.59\lesssim\theta\lesssim 0.94, none of the two pure states can individually violate the covariance Bell inequality (6), whereas the mixture (33) does violate it. This effect is possible only via the nonlinearity of the covariance Bell inequality.

Note that the pure states |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle and |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle and the mixture ρ𝜌\rho give in fact the same correlation functions ⟨Ax​By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦\langle A_{x}B_{y}\rangle for any (projective) Pauli measurements A^x=σ^Axsubscript^𝐴𝑥subscript^𝜎subscript𝐴𝑥\hat{A}_{x}=\hat{\sigma}_{A_{x}} and B^y=σ^Bysubscript^𝐵𝑦subscript^𝜎subscript𝐵𝑦\hat{B}_{y}=\hat{\sigma}_{B_{y}} for Alice and Bob. The difference resides in the marginals ⟨Ax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥\langle A_{x}\rangle and ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle, which are opposite for |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle and |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle and are therefore unbiased for the equal mixture ρθsubscript𝜌𝜃\rho_{\theta}.

Let us finally mention that we also investigated quantum violations of inequality (6) using mixed entangled states of rank 3 and higher (up to dimension 6×6666\times 6). We always found that the optimal violations were obtained with pure or rank-2 states. It thus seems that mixing more than 2 pure entangled states does not help increase the violations.

Appendix D Optimal local strategies and violations for our covariance Bell inequalities (9)–(10)

In this Appendix we present some local strategies that reach the local bounds of our Bell inequalities (9) and (10), and show how these can be violated quantum mechanically and by non-signalling correlations. Recall that the local bounds were obtained numerically; however, we are confident that the numerics are trustworthy enough, and therefore that the local strategies we present below are indeed optimal.

D.1 Covariance Bell inequality (9)

D.1.1 Optimal local strategies

To obtain the local bound for cov3322 we ran a numerical optimization several times and conclude from the stability of the result that it must be 9292\frac{9}{2}, as in inequality (9).

There are 4 different local distributions that give the value cov3322=92cov332292\text{cov3322}=\frac{9}{2}, and that decompose onto three deterministic correlations with weights 3838\frac{3}{8}, 3838\frac{3}{8} and 1414\frac{1}{4}: namely, P=38(+++/+++)+38(−−+/−−+)+14(−+−/−+−)P=\frac{3}{8}(+++/+++)+\frac{3}{8}(--+/--+)+\frac{1}{4}(-+-/-+-), P=38(+++/++−)+38(−−+/−−−)+14(+−−/−++)P=\frac{3}{8}(+++/++-)+\frac{3}{8}(--+/---)+\frac{1}{4}(+--/-++) (using here the notation (A0​A1​A2/B0​B1​B2)subscript𝐴0subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵0subscript𝐵1subscript𝐵2(A_{0}A_{1}A_{2}/B_{0}B_{1}B_{2})), and the other 2 “opposite decompositions”, where all outputs are flipped.

D.1.2 Violations of inequality (9)

Inequality (9) can be violated by quantum correlations. For example, taking a two-qubit maximally entangled state |ϕ+⟩=12​(|0,0⟩+|1,1⟩)ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ12ket00ket11\left|\phi_{+}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\left|0,0\right\rangle+\left|1,1\right\rangle) and suitable measurements (see below), one can obtain cov3322=5absent5=5, which is also the highest value for I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322} (Eq. (8)) obtainable with qubits and projective measurements froissart ; sliwa ; CG (note that in that case, all marginal terms vanish and cov3322 effectively reduces to I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322}). We have performed an extensive numerical search, considering entangled states of dimension up to 5×5555\times 5, and could not find any larger quantum violation than cov3322=5. It thus remains an open question, whether higher dimensional entangled states could lead to larger violations, as it is the case for the standard I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322} inequality tamas2 .

Considering again the families of states |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle, |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle and ρθsubscript𝜌𝜃\rho_{\theta} of Eqs. (31)–(33), the largest values of cov3322 we found (numerically, up to machine precision) are cov3322=5​sin⁡θcov33225𝜃\text{cov3322}=5\sin\theta for |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle or |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle (obtained e.g. for A^0=B^1=σ^xsubscript^𝐴0subscript^𝐵1subscript^𝜎x\hat{A}_{0}=\hat{B}_{1}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}, A^1=B^2=cos⁡π3​σ^x+sin⁡π3​σ^ysubscript^𝐴1subscript^𝐵2𝜋3subscript^𝜎x𝜋3subscript^𝜎y\hat{A}_{1}=\hat{B}_{2}=\cos\frac{\pi}{3}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}+\sin\frac{\pi}{3}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{y}}, A^2=−B^0=cos⁡2​π3​σ^x+sin⁡2​π3​σ^ysubscript^𝐴2subscript^𝐵02𝜋3subscript^𝜎x2𝜋3subscript^𝜎y\hat{A}_{2}=-\hat{B}_{0}=\cos\frac{2\pi}{3}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}+\sin\frac{2\pi}{3}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{y}}) and cov3322=4+sin2⁡θcov33224superscript2𝜃\text{cov3322}=4+\sin^{2}\theta for ρθsubscript𝜌𝜃\rho_{\theta} (obtained e.g. for A^0=B^0=1−sin2⁡θ4​σ^z+sin⁡θ2​σ^xsubscript^𝐴0subscript^𝐵01superscript2𝜃4subscript^𝜎z𝜃2subscript^𝜎x\hat{A}_{0}=\hat{B}_{0}=\sqrt{1-\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{4}}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}+\frac{\sin\theta}{2}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}, A^1=B^1=1−sin2⁡θ4​σ^z−sin⁡θ2​σ^xsubscript^𝐴1subscript^𝐵11superscript2𝜃4subscript^𝜎z𝜃2subscript^𝜎x\hat{A}_{1}=\hat{B}_{1}=\sqrt{1-\frac{\sin^{2}\theta}{4}}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{z}}-\frac{\sin\theta}{2}\,\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}, A^2=B^2=σ^xsubscript^𝐴2subscript^𝐵2subscript^𝜎x\hat{A}_{2}=\hat{B}_{2}=\hat{\sigma}_{\textsc{x}}). These violate inequality (9) for θ>arcsin⁡9/25≃1.12𝜃925similar-to-or-equals1.12\theta>\arcsin\frac{9/2}{5}\simeq 1.12 and θ>arcsin⁡92−4=π4𝜃924𝜋4\theta>\arcsin\sqrt{\frac{9}{2}-4}=\frac{\pi}{4}, respectively. As it was the case with covCHSH, we thus find a range of parameters (for π4<θ≲1.12𝜋4𝜃less-than-or-similar-to1.12\frac{\pi}{4}<\theta\lesssim 1.12) for which neither |ϕθ⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\left|\phi_{\theta}\right\rangle nor |ψθ⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝜃\left|\psi_{\theta}\right\rangle violates inequality (9), but their equal mixture does—which is a consequence of the nonlinearity of cov3322. Similarly to covCHSH this property does not seem to extend to mixtures of more than two pure states, that is, the violation of rank-3 states (or higher) does not appear to be larger than when mixing only two pure states. It is also interesting to note that within the families under consideration, cov3322 is violated by a smaller range of states than covCHSH. This is in contrast to the relationship between the standard CHSH and I3322subscript𝐼3322I_{3322} linear Bell inequalities, where all entangled (possibly mixed) quantum states violating (a symmetry of) the former also violate the latter CG .777This can indeed be seen as follows: taking A^2=B^0=−𝟙subscript^𝐴2subscript^𝐵0𝟙\hat{A}_{2}=\hat{B}_{0}=-\openone, the expression of cov3322 in Eq. (8) simplifies to I3322=⟨A0​B1⟩+⟨A0​B2⟩+⟨A1​B1⟩−⟨A1​B2⟩+2=CHSH01/12+2subscript𝐼3322delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵22subscriptCHSH01122I_{3322}=\langle A_{0}B_{1}\rangle+\langle A_{0}B_{2}\rangle+\langle A_{1}B_{1}\rangle-\langle A_{1}B_{2}\rangle+2=\text{CHSH}_{01/12}+2, where CHSH01/12subscriptCHSH0112\text{CHSH}_{01/12} is a symmetry of CHSH, Eq. (3). Clearly if there exist measurement operators giving CHSH01/12>2subscriptCHSH01122\text{CHSH}_{01/12}>2, one then also gets a value I3322>4subscript𝐼33224I_{3322}>4. Note that the same argument does not extend to covCHSH and cov3322: for the choice of A^2=B^0=−𝟙subscript^𝐴2subscript^𝐵0𝟙\hat{A}_{2}=\hat{B}_{0}=-\openone, we just get cov3322=covCHSH01/12≤4cov3322subscriptcovCHSH01124\text{cov3322}=\text{covCHSH}_{01/12}\leq 4, so that no violation of inequality (9) is possible with those measurement settings.

Note, finally, that the algebraic maximum value of cov3322=8cov33228\text{cov3322}=8 can be attained by the non-signalling distributions such that ⟨A0​B0⟩=⟨A0​B1⟩=⟨A0​B2⟩=⟨A1​B0⟩=⟨A1​B1⟩=−⟨A0​B2⟩=⟨A2​B0⟩=−⟨A2​B1⟩=1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵2delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵11\langle A_{0}B_{0}\rangle=\langle A_{0}B_{1}\rangle=\langle A_{0}B_{2}\rangle=\langle A_{1}B_{0}\rangle=\langle A_{1}B_{1}\rangle=-\langle A_{0}B_{2}\rangle=\langle A_{2}B_{0}\rangle=-\langle A_{2}B_{1}\rangle=1 (with ⟨A2​B2⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵2\langle A_{2}B_{2}\rangle remaining a free parameter) and with all marginals ⟨Ax⟩=⟨By⟩=0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦0\langle A_{x}\rangle=\langle B_{y}\rangle=0. Such distributions also reach the maximal non-signalling value of I3322=8subscript𝐼33228I_{3322}=8.

D.2 Bell inequality (10) for Pearson correlators

D.2.1 Optimal local strategies with binary outputs a,b=±1𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1a,b=\pm 1

For the case of binary outputs (taking e.g. a,b=±1𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1a,b=\pm 1) we find, again numerically, that the local bound for rCHSH is 5252\frac{5}{2}, as in inequality (10). This bound can be reached by the 888 distributions that decompose as mixtures of the same triplets of deterministic distributions Pk1detsuperscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘1detP_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}, Pk2detsuperscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘2detP_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}, Pk3detsuperscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘3detP_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}} as those in Table 1 of Appendix A (i.e., those that allow one to reach the local bound of the covariance inequality (6)), but taking here uniform mixtures, P=13​Pk1det+13​Pk2det+13​Pk3det𝑃13superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘1det13superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘2det13superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝑘3detP=\frac{1}{3}P_{k_{1}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{3}P_{k_{2}}^{\text{det}}+\frac{1}{3}P_{k_{3}}^{\text{det}}. E.g., for the first one: P=13(++/++)+13(−+/−−)+13(−−/−+)P=\frac{1}{3}(++/++)+\frac{1}{3}(-+/--)+\frac{1}{3}(--/-+).

D.2.2 Optimal local strategies with ternary outputs a,b=+1,0,−1formulae-sequence𝑎𝑏101a,b=+1,0,-1

As emphasized before, in the case of Pearson correlators, considering binary outputs or a larger alphabet of possible outputs does make a difference. As shown in Appendix B.2, the value of rCHSH, for any choice of possible outputs, that can be reached locally is upper-bounded by 2​2222\sqrt{2}. As it turns out, this bound can be reached with ternary outputs a,b=+1,0,−1formulae-sequence𝑎𝑏101a,b=+1,0,-1, for instance by the local distribution P=49(++/+0)+49(+−/0+)+19(00/−−)P=\frac{4}{9}(++/+0)+\frac{4}{9}(+-/0+)+\frac{1}{9}(00/--).

Note that if any output variable Axsubscript𝐴𝑥A_{x} or Bysubscript𝐵𝑦B_{y} is deterministic, its variance is zero and by convention we took r​(Ax,By)=0rsubscript𝐴𝑥subscript𝐵𝑦0\text{r}(A_{x},B_{y})=0. This implies that rCHSH defined in Eq. (10) contains at most 2 nonzero Pearson correlators, which implies that rCHSH≤2rCHSH2\text{rCHSH}\leq 2. Furthermore, if the two output variables of any party are both deterministic, then rCHSH=0rCHSH0\text{rCHSH}=0. Nevertheless, one can also locally reach a value of rCHSH arbitrarily close to the bound 2​2222\sqrt{2} by certain distributions that get arbitrarily close to some deterministic ones: e.g., P=(1−ϵ)(++/+0)+ϵ2(+−/−+)+ϵ2(−+/−−)P=(1-\epsilon)(++/+0)+\frac{\epsilon}{2}(+-/-+)+\frac{\epsilon}{2}(-+/--) with 0<ϵ<10italic-ϵ10<\epsilon<1 gives rCHSH=2​(1+1−ϵ)/2−ϵ→2​2rCHSH211italic-ϵ2italic-ϵ→22\text{rCHSH}=2(1+\sqrt{1-\epsilon})/\sqrt{2-\epsilon}\to 2\sqrt{2} as ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0\epsilon\to 0 (note that Alice still has a binary output ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 here; only Bob has a ternary output +1,0,−1101+1,0,-1, for one of his inputs only). Hence, in this case the value of rCHSH cannot be used as a shared randomness witness.

D.2.3 Violations of inequality (10)

As proven in Appendix B, the Tsirelson bound for rCHSH is 2​2222\sqrt{2}, which can be reached by adequate (binary) projective measurements on a maximally 2-qubit entangled states. The quantum correlations thus obtained thus violate the inequality (10) (with the local bound 5252\frac{5}{2}, for the case where one restricts to binary outputs), but do not violate the analogous inequality for arbitrary outcomes, when the local bound also becomes 2​2222\sqrt{2} (see above).

We note that for rCHSH, the nonlinearity of the Bell expression does not seem to exhibit the same interesting features as covCHSH and cov3322 presented in the previous appendices: the maximal value of a mixture of pure states appears, from our numerical investigations, to always be attained by one of the pure states.

Finally, note that algebraic maximum of rCHSH=4 can be obtained by a PR box (just as for CHSH and covCHSH).

Appendix E Minimal amount of shared randomness required to reach a given value of covCHSH

In this appendix we provide the details on how one can find the minimal amount of shared randomness—quantified here in terms of the Shannon entropy H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda)—required to locally reach a given value of covCHSH.

A general local model provides a decomposition for the probabilities P​(a,b|x,y)𝑃𝑎conditional𝑏𝑥𝑦P(a,b|x,y) as in Eq. (1). Our aim is thus to estimate the function

min⁡HΛgen​(c)≡minlocal distributions (1)giving covCHSH=c⁡H​(Λ),superscriptsubscript𝐻Λgen𝑐subscriptlocal distributions (1)giving covCHSH𝑐𝐻Λ\displaystyle\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{gen}}(c)\equiv\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\text{local distributions\leavevmode\nobreak\ \eqref{eq:local}}\\ \text{giving }\text{covCHSH}=c\end{subarray}}H(\Lambda), (34)

for any value of c𝑐c between 00 and 167167\frac{16}{7}.

Rather than considering general local decompositions directly, it is in fact useful to first concentrate on the case of binary outputs a,b=±1𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1a,b=\pm 1, and consider decompositions onto deterministic local response functions—that is, with PA​(a|x,λ),PB​(b|y,λ)subscript𝑃𝐴conditional𝑎𝑥𝜆subscript𝑃𝐵conditional𝑏𝑦𝜆P_{A}(a|x,\lambda),P_{B}(b|y,\lambda) equal to 00 or 111. We shall thus first estimate the function

min⁡HΛdet​(c)≡minlocal distributions (1)with ​a,b=±1​ and ​PA,PB=0,1giving covCHSH=c⁡H​(Λ),superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐subscriptlocal distributions (1)formulae-sequencewith 𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1 and subscript𝑃𝐴subscript𝑃𝐵01giving covCHSH𝑐𝐻Λ\displaystyle\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)\equiv\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\text{local distributions\leavevmode\nobreak\ \eqref{eq:local}}\\ \text{with }a,b=\pm 1\text{ and }P_{A},P_{B}=0,1\\ \text{giving }\text{covCHSH}=c\end{subarray}}H(\Lambda),\quad (35)

which clearly satisfies min⁡HΛdet​(c)≥min⁡HΛgen​(c)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐻Λgen𝑐\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)\geq\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{gen}}(c). We will then prove that these two functions in fact coincide: to reach the minimal amount of shared randomness for a given value of covCHSH, it is indeed enough to just consider binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1, and decompositions onto deterministic local response functions.

E.1 Local decompositions onto deterministic response functions with binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1

Let us first note that for binary inputs and binary outputs, there is only a finite number (161616) of local deterministic strategies for Alice and Bob together. Even though the local decomposition (1) with deterministic response functions may involve more than 161616 different values for λ𝜆\lambda (and even continuous values, in an appropriate limit), clearly the entropy H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda) is minimized when the different values of λ𝜆\lambda that define the same deterministic strategies are grouped together. This implies that it is sufficient to consider here local decompositions of the form P=∑kqk​Pkdet𝑃subscript𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘detP=\sum_{k}q_{k}P_{k}^{\text{det}} onto the 161616 different deterministic distributions Pkdetsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘detP_{k}^{\text{det}}. The optimization problem in Eq. (35) then reduces to optimize the 161616 weights qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} under the constraints qk≥0subscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k}\geq 0, ∑kqk=1subscript𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘1\sum_{k}q_{k}=1 and covCHSH​({qk}k)=ccovCHSHsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑘𝑐\text{covCHSH}(\{q_{k}\}_{k})=c.

We performed this optimization numerically, for various values of c=covCHSH𝑐covCHSHc=\text{covCHSH}. Our results are shown on Fig. 2 (the function min⁡HΛdetsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}} coincides with min⁡H​(Λ)𝐻Λ\min H(\Lambda) shown there). We repeated the numerical optimization several times, starting with different random starting points; the consistency of the results we obtained make us confident that we indeed reached the global minima in Eq. (35).

What we found (up to numerical precision) is that for c=covCHSH≤2𝑐covCHSH2c=\text{covCHSH}\leq 2, the minimum in (35) is reached by mixing only 222 deterministic local distributions with nonzero weights: for instance, taking P=q(++/++)+(1−q)(−−/−−)P=q(++/++)+(1{-}q)(--/--) gives covCHSH=8​q​(1−q)covCHSH8𝑞1𝑞\text{covCHSH}=8q(1{-}q), H​(Λ)=H​({q,1−q})=−q​log2⁡q−(1−q)​log2⁡(1−q)𝐻Λ𝐻𝑞1𝑞𝑞subscript2𝑞1𝑞subscript21𝑞H(\Lambda)=H(\{q,1{-}q\})=-q\log_{2}q-(1{-}q)\log_{2}(1{-}q), and leads (for 0≤c≤20𝑐20\leq c\leq 2) to min⁡HΛdet​(c)=h2​(1−c/2)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐subscriptℎ21𝑐2\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)=h_{2}(\sqrt{1-c/2}), with the binary entropy function h2​(x)=−1+x2​log2⁡1+x2−1−x2​log2⁡1−x2subscriptℎ2𝑥1𝑥2subscript21𝑥21𝑥2subscript21𝑥2h_{2}(x)=-\frac{1+x}{2}\log_{2}\frac{1+x}{2}-\frac{1-x}{2}\log_{2}\frac{1-x}{2}.

For 2<c=covCHSH≤167≃2.292𝑐covCHSH167similar-to-or-equals2.292<c=\text{covCHSH}\leq\frac{16}{7}\simeq 2.29, we found that the minimum in (35) is reached by mixing now 333 deterministic local distributions with nonzero weights: for instance, with distributions of the form P=q1(++/++)+q2(−+/−−)+q3(−−/−+)P=q_{1}(++/++)+q_{2}(-+/--)+q_{3}(--/-+). That gives covCHSH=(1−q1)​(1+7​q1)−(q2−q3)2covCHSH1subscript𝑞117subscript𝑞1superscriptsubscript𝑞2subscript𝑞32\text{covCHSH}=(1-q_{1})(1+7q_{1})-(q_{2}-q_{3})^{2}, H​(Λ)=H​({q1,q2,q3})𝐻Λ𝐻subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3H(\Lambda)=H(\{q_{1},q_{2},q_{3}\}).
