We note that as can clearly be seen on Fig. 2, min⁡HΛdetsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}} is a (strictly) increasing function of c=covCHSH𝑐covCHSHc=\text{covCHSH}.

E.2 General local decompositions

For a general local decomposition of the form (1), one gets

covCHSH
=∫ρ(λ)[⟨A0⟩λ(⟨B0⟩λ−⟨B0⟩+⟨B1⟩λ−⟨B1⟩)\displaystyle=\!\int\!\!\rho(\lambda)\big{[}\langle A_{0}\rangle_{\lambda}\;(\langle B_{0}\rangle_{\lambda}{-}\langle B_{0}\rangle{+}\langle B_{1}\rangle_{\lambda}{-}\langle B_{1}\rangle)
+⟨A1⟩λ(⟨B0⟩λ−⟨B0⟩−⟨B1⟩λ+⟨B1⟩)]dλ\displaystyle\qquad\qquad+\langle A_{1}\rangle_{\lambda}\;(\langle B_{0}\rangle_{\lambda}{-}\langle B_{0}\rangle{-}\langle B_{1}\rangle_{\lambda}{+}\langle B_{1}\rangle)\big{]}d\lambda\qquad (36)

with ⟨Ax⟩λ=∑aa​P​(a|x,λ)subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥𝜆subscript𝑎𝑎𝑃conditional𝑎𝑥𝜆\langle A_{x}\rangle_{\lambda}=\sum_{a}a\,P(a|x,\lambda) and ⟨By⟩λ=∑bb​P​(b|y,λ)subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦𝜆subscript𝑏𝑏𝑃conditional𝑏𝑦𝜆\langle B_{y}\rangle_{\lambda}=\sum_{b}b\,P(b|y,\lambda) (so that ⟨Ax⟩=∫ρ​(λ)​⟨Ax⟩λ​𝑑λdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥𝜌𝜆subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴𝑥𝜆differential-d𝜆\langle A_{x}\rangle=\int\rho(\lambda)\langle A_{x}\rangle_{\lambda}d\lambda and similarly for ⟨By⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵𝑦\langle B_{y}\rangle).

Looking at this expression, it is clear that for a given distribution ρ​(λ)𝜌𝜆\rho(\lambda) (and therefore a given value of H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda)) and some given response functions of Bob, the maximal value of covCHSH is obtained when |⟨A0⟩λ|=1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐴0𝜆1|\langle A_{0}\rangle_{\lambda}|=1, i.e., when Alice uses deterministic response functions with output ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 (specifically, Alice’s optimal response function is Ax​(λ)=sign​[⟨B0⟩λ−⟨B0⟩+(−1)x​(⟨B1⟩λ−⟨B1⟩)]subscript𝐴𝑥𝜆signdelimited-[]subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵0𝜆delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵0superscript1𝑥subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵1𝜆delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝐵1A_{x}(\lambda)=\text{sign}[\langle B_{0}\rangle_{\lambda}{-}\langle B_{0}\rangle{+}(-1)^{x}(\langle B_{1}\rangle_{\lambda}{-}\langle B_{1}\rangle)]).

A similar reasoning can be followed for Bob. We then conclude that for a given value of H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda), the maximal value of covCHSH is obtained when Alice and Bob use deterministic response functions with outputs a,b=±1𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1a,b=\pm 1: essentially, local randomness (or considering other possible outputs in [−1,+1]11[-1,+1]) does not help increase the value of covCHSH.

Note, however, that the optimization problem in Eq. (34) is subtly different: rather than maximizing covCHSH for a given value of H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda), we want to mimimize H​(Λ)𝐻ΛH(\Lambda) for a given value of covCHSH. To conclude here we will use the previous observation, that min⁡HΛdet​(c)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c) is an increasing function of c=covCHSH𝑐covCHSHc=\text{covCHSH}.

Consider indeed a (general) local decomposition of a distribution P𝑃P with a given amount of shared randomness H​(Λ)=h𝐻ΛℎH(\Lambda)=h, and which gives some value covCHSH=ccovCHSH𝑐\text{covCHSH}=c. From the above reasoning, it follows that there exists another distribution P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} using the same shared random variable ΛΛ\Lambda (hence, with the same value H​(Λ)=h𝐻ΛℎH(\Lambda)=h) but now decomposed onto deterministic local response functions with binary outputs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1, that gives a value covCHSH=c′≥ccovCHSHsuperscript𝑐′𝑐\text{covCHSH}=c^{\prime}\geq c. This then implies that min⁡HΛdet​(c′)≤hsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdetsuperscript𝑐′ℎ\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c^{\prime})\leq h and, because min⁡HΛdetsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}} is an increasing function, min⁡HΛdet​(c)≤hsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐ℎ\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)\leq h as well. Hence, any general local decomposition that gives some value covCHSH=ccovCHSH𝑐\text{covCHSH}=c necessarily satisfies H​(Λ)≥min⁡HΛdet​(c)𝐻Λsuperscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐H(\Lambda)\geq\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c). This implies that min⁡HΛgen​(c)≥min⁡HΛdet​(c)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λgen𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{gen}}(c)\geq\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)—and therefore, min⁡HΛgen​(c)=min⁡HΛdet​(c)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λgen𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{gen}}(c)=\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c)—with min⁡HΛdet​(c)superscriptsubscript𝐻Λdet𝑐\min\!H_{\Lambda}^{\text{det}}(c) estimated above.
